Due to the serious greenhouse gas effects caused by the increasing concentration of atmospheric CO2, carbon capture and storage (CCS) has been an important area of research and many technologies are developed within this field. Molten salt CO2 capture and electrochemical transformation (MSCC-ET) process is a desirable method due to a high CO2 solubility, a wide potential window of molten salts and easily-controlled electrode reactions. Generally, electro-splitting CO2 in molten salts begins with CO2 absorption reactions to form CO3 2−, which is then followed by the carbon deposition at the cathode and O2 evolution at the anode. As a result, CO2 is electro-converted to O2 and carbon with different morphologies, compositions, microstructures and functional properties. This report introduces the MSCC-ET process, summarizes the reactions occurring in the molten salts and at the electrode surfaces, as well as the morphological variations of the cathodic products. The inert anode materials, cost estimation and scale-up evaluation of the process are then discussed. It is presumed that with a comprehensive understanding of the electrode reactions during electrolysis and the functional properties of carbon materials obtained during CO2 electro-splitting can provide a foundation for further developing this environmentally friendly process. Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 electro-splitting Molten salt electrolysis Inert anodes Cost evaluation 1 Introduction Reducing CO2 emissions has become a key issue for individuals and also a significant international strategy. As the most notorious greenhouse gas, it has been shown that doubling of atmospheric CO2 concentration in turn raises the surface earth temperature by 4 °C [1]. However, due to the enormous consumption of fossil fuels, the atmospheric CO2 concentration increased by one third in the past century and has currently reached record levels of roughly 406–410 ppm [2,3]. It has been forecasted by Davis [4,5] that 496 gigatons of CO2 will be generated by fossil fuel combustion between 2010 and 2060, which means that the atmospheric CO2 concentration will increase to about 500 ppm. If no changes in regulations are adopted, climate change, rising sea levels and the extinction of many species will be observed more in the near future [1,6]. On the other hand, CO2 is a useful carbon and oxygen resource. CO2 is the feedstock for the productions of urea, salicylic acid, carbamates and inorganic compounds [7–9]. Among these carbon-related products, the environmentally friendly advanced carbon materials are the important support for strategic emerging industries, showing great market potential. For example, high performance carbon/carbon composites are excellent structural materials due to the merits of low density, high strength and high-temperature resistance [10–12]. In addition, carbon is also commonly used as electrode materials for super-capacitors, lithium ions batteries and fuel cells [13–15]. If atmospheric CO2 can be converted to advanced carbon materials, the environmental burden can be reduced. Therefore, it can be suggested that the acquisition of value-added carbon materials from CO2-containing exhaust gas is an attractive potential technology, due to the advantages of low-cost feedstock and governmental policy support [6]. Molten salt CO2 capture and electrochemical transformation (MSCC-ET) process is a preferable method for the conversion of CO2 to advanced carbon materials [1,16–18]. Electrons are the strongest reducing agent, guaranteeing a fast electrochemical reaction at mild conditions. Also, electrochemical reactions are easy to control by adjusting the electrode potential and current density [19]. Therefore, the capture and electrochemical conversion of CO2 to value-added materials in aqueous solution, room temperature ionic liquids (RTILs) and molten salts have been widely explored [16,20,21]. However, electrochemical conversion rate of CO2 in aqueous solution is very low due to a low CO2 solubility [20]. In addition, there is a competing reduction reactions for H2O, leading to a considerable current efficiency loss [16,18]. Furthermore, catalysts with complex structures are needed for CO2 conversion in aqueous solutions [20]. Although the CO2 solubility in RTILs is higher, the high cost of RTILs as well as slow reaction kinetics prevents them from widespread adoption in commercial applications [18,22]. Compared with the aqueous solution and RTILs, the low-cost inorganic molten salts have many advantages. Firstly, inorganic molten salts have a wide potential window, which means that few side reactions happen during the CO2 electro-reduction, contributing to a high current efficiency [23,24]. Secondly, compared to low-temperature electrolytes, high-temperature molten salts can promote the diffusion of electro-active ions and electrode reactions, contributing to a very high CO2 conversion rate. Thirdly, no complex or expensive catalysts are needed, therefore, high productivity of advanced carbon materials can be realized by processing CO2-containing flue gas at a low cost [16,25]. Furthermore, molten salts have a very high CO2 solubility, providing a high-flux uptake rate for deep removal of CO2. Finally, other pollutants in the flue gas such as NO2 and SO2, which are a big challenge for other technologies due to their poisoning effect on catalysts [26], can be absorbed and simultaneous doped into the cathode products to increase the functional ability of electrodeposited carbon in molten salts [26]. Therefore, instead of being harmful flue gas components, SO2 and NO2 can potentially become beneficial constituents for electro-deposition of value-added S/N-doped carbon materials, removing the need for pre-separation and concentration of the flue gas [2,26]. The commercially successful application of molten salt electrolysis has also been demonstrated, during the extractions of aluminum, alkaline and alkaline-earth metals, showing the potential large-scale commercialization for electrochemical conversion of CO2 in molten salts. Moreover, molten salts possess a high heat capacity, providing a high possibility for integrating molten salt electrolysis technology with photovoltaic and photo-thermal systems, reducing the environmental impact further [19,27,28]. For the MSCC-ET process, carbon and O2 are the CO2-splitting products on the cathode and anode, respectively. The value of electro-deposited carbon is determined by its physicochemical properties while the O2 evolution on the anode guarantees a green process. Therefore, research about the MSCC-ET process mainly focuses on two aspects: (1) the properties of electro-deposited carbon including the morphology, particle size and specific surface areas, and (2) explorations of inert anode materials for oxygen evolution. In this paper, the progress toward controllable electro-deposition of carbon from CO2 in molten salts with various morphologies and functional properties is reviewed. Moreover, the corrosive mechanisms for different inert anodes used by MSCC-ET process are discussed. Finally, the cost analysis for the MSCC-ET process is also conducted. 2 The MSCC-ET process The MSCC-ET process, which involves the capture of CO2 using molten salt and electrochemical transformation into value-added carbon materials, is illustrated in Fig. 1 . Generally, the MSCC-ET process consists of two consecutive reactions [2,16]: CO2 is firstly captured to form C( n +1)O( n +3) 2− (such as CO3 2−or C2O5 2−) on the gas–liquid surfaces with the aid of O2−, and then the formed C( n +1)O( n +3) 2− complex is reduced to carbon on the cathode. Simultaneously, O2 is released on the inert anode surface. 2.1 CO2 capture CO2 absorption and conversion in molten salts are fulfilled by the consecutive reactions of carbonation and electrochemical reduction. In the view of continuous operation, the electrochemical reduction rate should be well matched with that of CO2 capture, achieving a net transformation of CO2. The electrochemical reduction rate can be easily tuned by adjusting the electrode potential and current density [2,22,29]. Therefore, the net CO2 transformation rate was mainly determined by the CO2 absorption process. A high CO2 absorption rate was also beneficial to the high-flux uptake and deep removal of CO2 in the flue gas. 2.1.1 Understanding of CO2 capture process The MSCC-ET process is usually conducted in carbonate-containing molten salts, in which CO3 2− undergoes an equilibrium decomposition reaction [30,31]: (1) CO3 2−⇄ CO2  + O2− It means that O2− co-exists with CO3 2− in the carbonate molten salts. Therefore, possible reactions for CO2 capture are as follows [2,18,30,31]: (2) CO2 + O2− = CO3 2− (3) CO2 + CO3 2− = C2O5 2− Licht et al. [32,33] observed significant mass loss of molten Li2CO3 at various temperatures (Fig. 2 a), providing evidence for the presence of reaction (1). Deng et al. [2,17] observed mass gain when CO2 was injected into the Li2O-containing molten salts (Fig. 2b), indicating that CO2 can be captured by reaction (2). Peeters et al. [30,31] confirmed that C2O5 2− is stable in molten carbonates, using both theoretical calculations and experimental results, implying reaction (3) also occurs during the CO2 capture process. Both reaction (2) and (3) contribute to the CO2 capture, however, understanding the main contributing factor is beneficial to maximize the capture capacity of molten salts. Deng et al. [2,17] compared the amounts of absorbed CO2 in carbonate molten salts containing different Li2O concentrations. As shown in Fig. 2(b), in the Li2O-free carbonate molten salts, the absorbed CO2 was roughly 7.5 mmol, which is an evidence for the absorption of CO2 by reaction (3). The absorbed amounts of CO2 increased obviously after addition of Li2O. When 5 wt% Li2O was added, the absorbed CO2 amount increased remarkably to nearly 110 mmol, about 13 times higher than that for pure carbonates. Considering that the CO3 2− concentration is almost constant in bulk carbonate molten salts, the addition of Li2O can promote the reaction (2) while having little influence on reaction (3). Hence, it can be speculated that the absorbed CO2 via reaction (2) was higher than 102.5 mmol while the CO2 capture amount contributed by reaction (3) would remain at roughly 7.5 mmol when 5 wt% Li2O was added. Claes et al. [30,31] found that the acidity of CO2, CO3 2− and C2O5 2− obeys the order of CO2  > CO3 2−  > C2O5 2−. Therefore, when alkaline oxides are added into the molten salt, reaction (2) will take place easier than that of reaction (3). In conclusion, it has been shown previously that reaction (2) is the main contributing factor for CO2 capture. 2.1.2 Thermodynamics and kinetics for CO2 absorption To further improve the capture ability of molten salts, the thermodynamic and kinetic activity for reaction (2) needs to be investigated in detail. In reaction (2), O2− was mainly donated by alkaline or alkaline earth oxides. The species and existing states of oxides will affect their reactivity for CO2 capture. Furthermore, reaction (2) is also influenced by the CO2 pressure, the activities of CO3 2− and O2− as well as the temperature. The reduction product at temperatures lower than 800 °C, in a pure carbonate molten salt, was carbon and gradually shifted to a mix of carbon and CO by increasing the temperature. Further increasing the temperature to exceed 950 °C, the electrolysis product at the cathode became pure CO [32]. At low temperatures, carbon deposition was the dominant reaction at the cathode in metal carbonate molten salts. During the electrolysis of pure Li2CO3 at 900 °C, only CO was detected in the cathode gas and no carbon was deposited. Therefore, at high temperatures, CO was released by reaction (23) [50,51]: (23) CO3 2−  + 2e− = CO + 2O2− At temperatures lower than 800 °C, carbon deposition was dominant in carbonate molten salts while CO evolution as well as carbon deposition took place simultaneously in chloride molten salts. At temperatures higher than 950 °C, CO evolution was the only cathode reduction in both carbonate and chloride molten salts. 2.3 Anodic oxygen evolution reactions O2 evolution at the anode guaranteed a green process for CO2 conversion. Both CO2 and O2 in the anodic gas were detected during electrolysis in the eutectic Li2CO3 Na2CO3–K2CO3 molten salt at 500 °C. This indicated that O2 is released by reactions (24) and (25) [16,50]. (24) 2O2 − = O2  + 4e− (25) 3CO3 2 − = O2  + 3CO2  + O2 − + 4e− In the eutectic Li2CO3 Na2CO3-K2CO3 molten salt at 500 °C, reaction (24) was the only anodic reaction noted at a low current density (9.95 mA cm−2) and low polarization. However, the ratio of CO2/O2 increased with increasing current density, indicating that reaction (25) proceeds easier at a high current density and polarization [25,52]. However, CO2 was not detected in the anode gas during electrolysis in Li2CO3 molten salt at 900 °C [50], indicating that reaction (24) was the dominant reaction at high temperatures. (26) CO2  = C + O2 (27) 2CO2 = 2CO + O2 By combining the electrode reactions with the CO2 absorption process, the net reactions for CO2 splitting can be described by reaction (26) at low temperatures or reaction (27) at high temperatures. Depending on reaction (27), O2 and CO were generated at the anode and cathode regions respectively at temperatures exceeding 900 °C [50]. However, the electrode and electrolysis bath materials were heavily corroded by carbonate molten salts at such a high temperature, impeding the practicability for CO production [50,51]. Therefore, it is suggested that electro-deposition of carbon should proceed on much more mild conditions. For example, carbon can be electro-deposited at a low temperature of 450 °C, which means that materials for an inert anode, cathode as well as electrolysis bath do not need to function in extreme conditions. Additionally, the electro-deposited carbon has a higher value than that of CO. Therefore, compared with CO, splitting CO2 into high value-added carbon materials in molten salts adds additional value to the process. 3 Carbon materials with various morphologies obtained by CO2 electro-splitting in molten salts and their applications The functional performance of the electro-deposited carbon is largely related to its morphology [22]. Therefore, to obtain carbon materials with high functional characteristics, morphological control is very important. By varying the molten salt composition, electrode materials, the applied current and the temperature, carbon materials with different morphologies can be obtained by the MSCC-ET process [3,25]. The reported morphologies of obtained carbon materials include hollow carbon spheres [37,48], carbon nanotubes [1,41,56–58], carbon nanofibers as well as graphene [59,62], which can be used as electrode materials in the lithium ion batteries and super-capacitors as well as catalyst supports. 3.1 Hollow carbon spheres As discussed above (shown in Fig. 4b), in CaCO3-containing chloride molten salts, CO evolution can occur simultaneously with carbon deposition at the cathode at low temperatures. The expansion of CO gas can shape the plastic ultrathin carbon sheets (Fig. 5 a, b), which was named the micro-bubble effect by Deng et al. [37,48]. By taking advantage of this phenomenon, hollow carbon spheres (HCSs) were obtained (Fig. 5c) [37]. Specifically, micro-sized HCSs can only be obtained at 450 °C with an applied cell voltage of 2.8 V, a very moderate condition. During electrolysis, the intermediate product, CO2 2−, can be chemically decomposed, forming CO or electrochemically reduced to carbon by reaction (18). A high cell voltage can promote the electrochemically transformation of CO2 2− to carbon, unfavorable for the occurrence of the micro-bubble effect. Moreover, ultrathin carbon sheets with high plasticity favors the bubble effect. However, high temperatures can decrease the plasticity of carbon sheets. Therefore, CO2 electro-splitting at low temperatures and cell voltages is beneficial to the formation of HCSs. 3.2 Low-temperature conversion of CO2 to graphite Industrially, the graphitization process is realized at temperatures exceeding 2700 °C [53]. However, during molten salt electrolysis process, cathodic polarization and the accompanying surface chemical reactions can provide a low-temperature graphitization process [54,55]. The cathodic polarization in molten salts can promote the surface deoxygenation and long-distance rearrangement of carbon atoms, thus facilitating to the graphitization process [55]. A schematic depiction of the direct conversion of amorphous carbon to graphite by cathodic polarization is shown in Fig. 6 (a). In addition to cathodic polarization, increasing the electrolysis temperature can also promote the graphitization process [18,35,36,40,54]. By increasing the temperature from 475 to 825 °C, the CO2 electro-splitting product at the cathode were gradually converted from amorphous carbons to crystalline graphite [54], which was verified by the XRD and Raman results as shown in Fig. 6(b, c). The presence of SO4 2− was another factor contributing to the graphitization process. Crystalline graphite was synthesized from the flue gas (a mixture of CO2 and SO2) in the Li2CO3 Na2CO3 K2CO3 Na2SO4 quaternary melt by the MSCC-ET process [54]. In the SO4 2−-containing melt, S and S2− can be generated on the cathode. S can combine with the imperfect carbon atoms in the carbon matrix to form CS2 while S2− can react with oxygen atom in the graphite to form SO2, both enhance the graphitization process [54]. 3.3 Carbon nanotubes Compared to conventional graphite materials, hollow core carbon nanotubes (CNTs) possess superior properties as functional materials. Conventionally, CNTs are produced by a chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method, a low productivity, high cost and complex process [1]. However, CNTs can also be obtained by electro-splitting CO2 in molten salts. The gaseous carbon source for CNTs deposition used in the CVD method is of a much lower concentration than liquid CO3 2− ions in molten salts. Therefore, the deposition speed of CNTs via molten salt electrolysis process is higher than that of CVD method [1]. In addition, catalysts with specific arrangement order should be elaborately designed, prior to deposition, for the CVD method, which challenge the production of high-quality CNTs. Alternatively, a bulk-phase cathode, without special modifications, can be used as the nucleation site for CNTs during electro-deposition. This alteration simplifies the CNTs production process. Furthermore, by tuning the electrolysis conditions, CNTs with various morphologies can be obtained, greatly extending the functional properties of CNTs [22]. Therefore, preparation of CNTs by electro-splittig CO2 in molten salts provides a potential low-cost, simple and high-productivity process. Four key factors to obtain high-purity CNTs are: (1) nucleation agents, (2) pre-activation, (3) cathode electrode materials, and (4) molten salt composition. 3.3.1 Nucleation agents Trace transition metals such as Ni, Fe, Co and Cu in the electrolyte can act as the nucleation sites for CNTs formation [41,56]. Generally, these can be split into two groups: promoting nucleation and promoting growth and repair. Nucleation catalytic ability has the trend: Co > Pt > Ni > Cu, while, the growth and repair catalytic ability has the trend: Ni > Co > Pt > Cu [57]. Ni was the most investigated catalysts for CNTs formation [1,41,57]. When a pure steel cathode was used, only amorphous carbon was obtained. However, when a Zn-coated steel cathode was used as cathode, spherical carbon was formed, and further converted to CNTs with addition of trace NiO. The Ni and Zn metals act as the nucleation sites and initiators for CNTs formation, respectively [1,41,57]. When Ni was used as the anode, a small amount of generated NiO at the surface of the anode dissolved into the melt and functioned as the nucleation sites. As a result, CNTs can be formed even without NiO addition into the melt [58]. It should be noted that certain pairs of bi-metallic catalysts promote CNTs growth between 10 and 100 fold than single metals alone [1,57]. Using a Ni catalyst as an example, the order of growth and repair catalytic ability for Ni based bi-metallic catalysts are Ni + Mo > Ni + Cr > Ni + Co > Ni + Pt > Ni + Rd > Ni + Fe > Ni > Fe. By using a Ni/Cr based inert anode as the bi-metallic catalysts source, the growth of CNTs was extraordinarily promoted, resulting in the formation of CNT wools with diameters over 1 μm and lengths exceeding 1 mm [1]. According to the SEM and EDS results, the CNTs grow outward from the layered graphene at the transition metal catalyst sites [1]. From this observation, Johnson et al. [1] suggested the tip growth mechanism, which states that CNT propagation took place at the solid/liquid interface with the aid of catalysts [1], as shown in Fig. 7 (a). Another growth mechanism, referred to as the root growth mechanism, was also proposed [1]. However, the tip growth mechanism was suggested to be the dominate mechanism as it can maximize the catalysts exposure to the bulk electrolyte and will minimize bulk carbon(IV) diffusion constraints [1]. According to the SEM results, the vast majority of Ni nanoparticles are located at the carbon nanofiber tips (Fig. 7b), which further implies a tip growth mechanism [41]. 3.3.2 Low current pre-activation process Transition metal catalysts on the cathode can provide nucleation sites for the CNTs formation. With specifically controlling the electrolysis conditions, pre-electrodeposition of metal catalysts at the cathode can be realized, facilitating CNT growth. When the transition metal ions in the molten salt are the catalyst sources, a pre-activation process, conducted by applying a low current to allow the electro-deposition of metal catalysts at the cathode, is essential for the subsequent electrochemically CNT growth. Electrolysis initiated by a high current mainly leads to amorphous carbon deposition. However, when a low current, such as 0.05 A [59], is applied, the corresponding cell voltage is lower than 0.7 V. This is sufficient for the formation of nucleation sites on the cathode, but insufficient for carbon electro-deposition. After this activation process, homogeneous CNTs can be obtained by a subsequent high current electrolysis [57,59]. 3.3.3 Cathode electrode materials Cathode materials can influence the morphology and yield of CNTs. A Zn-coated steel cathode can contribute to the CNTs formation because the melt Zn in the molten salt can help to promote the dissolution of transition metal catalysts in the anode [41]. When 0.1%–0.4% metallic Ni powder was directly introduced to the melt as the nucleation catalysts, CNTs can also be obtained without the aid of Zn-coating by using a bare Monel (Ni–Cu alloy) cathode [41]. By introducing 0.4% Ni powder into the molten carbonate, the influence of various cathode materials on the morphologies of electro-deposited CNTs was systematically investigated by Licht et al. [57]. It was found that a high yield of CNTs can be produced when Monel, Cu, Ni, Ni + Cr, or graphite was used as the cathode. However, the morphologies are very different. For example, thin tangled CNTs were formed based on a Cu cathode while uniform, thicker and straight CNTs were obtained when a Monel cathode was used. In addition, the yield is also different for various cathode materials. The CNTs yield based on a Ni cathode (80%–85%) is lower than that based a copper cathode (>85%). When pure Fe and Ti cathodes were used, only CNTs with moderate quality (length and quantity of CNT) were obtained. It was recently noted that, after reaching an electrolyte equilibrium, by keeping the molten salt still for 24 h prior to electrolysis, high-quality CNT wools can be obtained on a bare Monel cathode substrate, without the need for transition metal catalysts and pre-electrolysis activation steps [1]. Sufficient electrolyte equilibration time is a significant determining factor for obtaining uniform CNT wools. The oxide/peroxide/superoxide speciation in the molten salt is time and cation dependent and the equilibrium process may affect the compositions of different oxides. Consequently, the electrochemical charge behavior was changed after electrolyte equilibrium. However, the mechanisms and theory behind the influence of electrolyte equilibrium still remain to be unknown. 3.3.4 Molten salt composition Molten carbonate and chloride salts are the most investigated systems. The compositions, such as cations and oxide concentration, can have a huge influence on the formation of CNTs. A thorough investigation into the influence of cations in the carbonate molten salt on the electrolysis products was investigated by Licht et al. [58,60]. In pure Li2CO3 molten salt, a high yield of CNTs can be obtained. However, only a marginal yield of CNTs was obtained in the LiNaK carbonate molten salt. Moreover, no carbon electro-deposition occurred in the Na2CO3–K2CO3 eutectic molten salt as the alkali metals were easier to generate in this system. However, in the LiNa and LiBa carbonate molten salts, a high yield of high-quality CNTs was obtained and the current efficiency was also very high. In addition to the commonly used LiNaK carbonate molten salt. An investigation into how the addition of CaCO3, MgCO3 and BaCO3 effects the morphology of cathode products was also investigated. Introduction of CaCO3 resulted in the formation of roughly 15% thinner-walled CNTs and 95% amorphous carbon. While, the electrolysis product with the addition of MgCO3 mainly consisted of honeycomb structured carbon [59]. The addition of oxide will also affect the CNTs morphology. In the molten carbonate without the addition of Li2O, straight CNTs were obtained. After addition of Li2O, the straight CNTs were converted into tangled CNTs [59]. In addition to carbonate molten salts, CNTs were also obtained in the LiCl–NaCl–Na2CO3 and NaCl–CaCl2-based molten salts when a nickel cathode was used [22,40,47,61]. In the NaCl–CaCl2-based molten salt, the morphology was highly related to the electrolysis temperature. At 650 °C, the obtained carbon shows a quasi-spherical morphology. By increasing the temperature to 750 °C, multi-walled CNTs with a high yield of nearly 100% was obtained. However, when the temperature was further increased to 850 °C, a bumpy and platelet-like carbon was obtained [22]. B-doped CNTs were synthesized by introducing LiBO2 into the carbonate molten salt [59]. After B-doping, the conductivity of the CNTs is improved. Similarly, other elements (S, N, P) doped CNTs can be obtained by adding a specific concentration of Na2SO4, LiPO3 or LiNO3 to the molten salts, respectively [57]. The doped CNTs show unusual properties such as high conductivity, heterogeneous catalysis, sorption, and energy conversion and storage [26,54]. 3.4 Sulfur-doped carbon electro-deposition Sulfur dioxide (SO2) is a usual ingredient in the CO2-containing flue gas. However, SO2 is a serious pollutant, causing acid rain and atmospheric particulate matter2.5 (PM2.5, particles with diameter of 2.5 micrometers or less). In addition, SO2 has a poisoning effect on many catalysts, which becomes a major concern on many CO2 capture and utilization (CCU) technologies. Therefore, pure CO2 feedstock is needed for these CCU technologies. This means that separation of CO2 from air or flue gas will inevitably increase the cost and challenges of these technologies [26]. Beyond that, simultaneous removal of SO2 to avoid its pollution to the environment has yet to be realized. On the other hand, S-doped carbon altered physicochemical properties and enhanced functionality in electrochemical energy storage/conversion devices are extensively reported [54]. Therefore, direct converting the SO2-containing flue gas to S-doped carbon materials has many advantages over alternative technologies. Molten salt CO2 capture and electrochemical conversion is a suitable process for directly converting the SO2-containing flue gas into S-doped carbon materials [26]. Firstly, SO2 is highly soluble in molten salts. As shown in Fig. 8 (a, b), after injecting the flue gas into the molten salt, both the concentration of CO2 and SO2 decreased significantly. Moreover, the SO2 concentration in the outlet gas was close to 0 ppm, indicating that instantaneous removal of SO2 can be achieved during the CO2 electro-splitting process. Secondly, SO2 can be converted into soluble SO4 2− and electrochemically reduced to S at the cathode [54]. Therefore, co-deposition of S and carbon can easily take place at the cathode, contributing to the in-situ formation of S-doped carbon materials (Fig. 8c). Furthermore, instead of challenging the CO2 capture process, utilizing SO2 in the flue gas results in value-added S-doped carbon materials by molten salt CO2 capture and electrochemical conversion process. The recycling utilization of SO2-containing flue gas is illustrated in Fig. 8(d). 3.5 Solid core carbon nanofibers By altering specific conditions, solid core carbon nanofibers (CNFs) can be obtained. For example, at the equivalent electrolysis conditions, 12CO2 favors the formation of CNTs (Fig. 9 a) while heavier 13CO2 contributes to CNFs electrodeposition (Fig. 9b) [59,62]. CO2 is dissolved in the molten salt and reduced at the cathode. Compared with 12CO3 2−, diffusion of the heavier 13CO3 2− is more difficult. Thereby influencing the distribution of transition metal nucleation sites, the curvature of the carbon cap as well as the availability of carbon during the growth process. This leads to the formation of solid core carbon nanofibers [33,59]. Influence of temperature, current, cell voltage and gaseous atmosphere have been extensively investigated, and well documented in current literatures [3,57,60]. Except the above mentioned carbon materials, other morphologies such as graphene [40], ultrathin graphite sheets [18], quasi-spheres [47] and amorphous carbon [63] synthesized by the molten salt electrolysis are also reported. There is further potential for other carbon materials, with unreported special morphologies, to be electro-synthesized in the molten salts. 3.6 Applications of the electro-synthesized carbon materials Due to special structures and high specific surface areas, the obtained carbon materials present superior properties when used as the electrode materials in batteries and super capacitors. In addition, the adsorption ability for heavy metals and the electro-catalysis ability for oxygen reduction reactions of synthesized carbon materials were also investigated. Licht et al. [62] investigated the energy storage properties of straight and tangled CNTs in lithium-ion battery. The results indicated that the tangled CNTs show a higher stable capacity (∼460 mAh g−1) than that (∼360 mAh g−1) of straight CNTs after 200 cycles at a current density of 100 mA g−1. Similarly, the tangle CNTs also show a better ability for Na+ storage than that of straight CNTs. The higher defect content and bending structure of tangled CNTs are likely to be the reasons leading to a superior capacity than that of straight CNTs. The energy storage properties of electro-deposited carbon, with different morphologies, were also studied as the battery materials [37,64]. After 500 cycles at a high current density of 500 mA g−1, the stable reversible specific capacities of HCSs and ultrathin carbon sheets were 254 and 185 mAh g−1, respectively, as shown in Fig. 10 (a) [37]. By comparing the capacity of carbon materials obtained at different cell voltages and temperatures, Tang et al. [64] found that the carbon electro-deposited at 450 °C with a cell voltage of 4.5 V shows remarkable rate performance and a stable capacity of 266 mAh g−1 when tested at a high current density of 500 mA g−1. These results indicated that the obtained carbon materials with specific morphologies still have a good capacity even at a high current density. In addition to Li-ion and Na-ion batteries, the electrodeposited carbon also shows good performances as the supercapacitor electrode materials. The HCSs presents a capacitance of 171 F g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 when tested in a 6 M KOH solution using a two-electrode cell [48]. As for the S-doped carbon derived from the flue gas, a higher capacitance of 257.3 F g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 was obtained when tested in a 1 M H2SO4 solution [26]. Compared with the carbon without S doping, the capacitances of S-doped carbon are much higher, as shown in Fig. 10(b). The eletro-catalytic property and heavy metal adsorption ability of the carbon materials obtained by the MSCC-ET process were also investigated [16,63,65]. Wang et al. [63] found that electrodeposited carbon was passive for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). However, after doping with S and Co by molten salt treatment, its catalytic activity for ORR reaction increased significantly, to a performance close to that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst [63]. Due to a porous structure and high specific surface area, the derived carbon materials by the MSCC-ET process also show a very high adsorption capacity for Cu2+, methylene and Cr6+ in aqueous solution, of 29.9 mg g−1, 302.5 mg g−1 and 49.5 mg g−1, respectively [16,65]. The above results indicated that the carbon materials derived from CO2 also show a good potential as the electro-catalysis and decontamination materials. 4 The inert anode materials used in the molten salt for CO2 electro-splitting An affordable and highly stable inert anode is a key prerequisite for the realization of a green process during the CO2 electro-splitting process in molten salts. Both molten carbonates and chlorides are used as electrolytes. Compared to molten chlorides, molten carbonates are less corrosive and generally have a lower melting point. Therefore, inert materials in molten carbonates are easier to achieve. On the other hand, the electrode reactions and physicochemical properties in chlorides differ greatly compared to molten carbonates, facilitating the preparation of carbon with useful morphologies and properties. Therefore, potential inert anode materials are also investigated in molten chlorides [66,69,70]. Generally, the inert anode materials include metals/alloys, ceramics and cermets [66]. Correspondingly, the explored inert anodes for CO2 electro-splitting in molten carbonates or molten chlorides include Ni-based alloys [41,60,67], SnO2 [3,68], RuO2-based materials [69], Pt [44]. 4.1 Ni-based alloys The anodic oxidation behavior of metallic Ni has been investigated in both molten chlorides and carbonates [66,71,72]. It has been noted that the stability of Ni anode can be remarkably improved by formation of a dense NiO layer on the surface [73–75]. However, the anodic dissolution behavior is very different in molten chlorides and carbonates. Ni-based alloys are not suitable as inert anodes in molten chlorides due to formation of NiCl2. Although formation of a dense insoluble NiO layer can retard the eletro-dissolution of metallic Ni, the consumption of NiO layer, by reacting with CaCl2 to form NiCl2, is inevitable during the long-term electrolysis [61,71], effecting the stability of metallic Ni as the inert anode in molten chlorides. In the molten carbonate salts, Cl− is absent and therefore NiCl2 formation is ruled out. In addition, the abundance of O2− in molten carbonates contributes to the rapid formation of a dense nickel oxides layer during anodic oxidation, increasing the stability of metal Ni anode. As shown in Fig. 11 (a) [66], two obvious oxidation peaks, with large anodic currents, were observed in the first cycle, which are related to the formation of NiO and Ni2O3 by oxidation of Ni. The anodic current decreased with continuing scanning (Fig. 11b), revealing the formation of a stable nickel oxide layer. In molten carbonates containing Li2CO3 and at low temperatures, however, Ni2O3 can be converted to soluble LiNiO2 during the anodic polarization process [66,72]. The corrosion of pure Ni anode was tested to be 12 mm per day in the Li2CO3 Na2CO3 K2CO3 molten salt at 500 °C [16], which means that pure metal Ni cannot be used as an inert anode for long-term electrolysis in Li2CO3-containing molten salt at low temperatures, however, corrosion can be restricted by increasing the temperature [72], as shown in Fig. 12 (a). This is because when the temperature exceeds 575 °C, instead of soluble LiNiO2, a stable and protective NiO film can be formed on the metal Ni surface during the anodic polarization process. The oxidation currents tested at high temperatures in the cyclic voltammogram curves are much lower than that tested at temperatures lower than 575 °C, as shown in Fig. 12(b, c). Thsee results further implied the formation of stable NiO films at high temperatures, retarding the corrosion of Ni anodes. When the pure metal Ni anode was replaced by a Ni10Cu11Fe alloy, a more stable NiFe2O4 film can be formed on the alloy surface in molten carbonates [66]. Due to the catalytic property of the NiFe2O4 film for oxygen evolution reaction (OER), the onset potential for oxygen evolution on the Ni10Cu11Fe alloy anode is 0.2 V more positive than that on a pure Ni anode (as shown in Fig. 11b) [66], suggesting a lower over potential for oxygen evolution on the alloy anode. Therefore, at temperatures exceeding 575 °C, a Ni-based alloy is a feasible inert anode in molten carbonates [72]. Furthermore, after electrolysis at 750 °C for 150 h in the Na2CO3–K2CO3 molten salt, the dimension and surface oxides protective layer of the Ni10Cu11Fe anode remained almost unchanged, proving the effectiveness and stability of the Ni10Cu11Fe alloy as the inert anode for oxygen evolution in molten carbonates at high temperatures [67]. In conclusion, Ni-based alloys are not suitable inert materials in molten chlorides. However, they have been shown to function as an effective inert anode in molten carbonate molten salts due to the formation of a stable oxide layer. Additionally, in a Li2CO3-containing molten salt, Ni-based metallic inert anodes are only stable at temperatures exceeding 575 °C. 4.2 SnO2 Due to a good electrical conductivity, easily preparation and an acceptable corrosion rate, SnO2-based anodes are one of the candidates for alumina electrolysis in cryolite molten salts [76]. For these reasons, the feasibility of SnO2 as the inert anode for the CO2 electro-splitting in carbonates or chlorides molten salts are also extensively explored [3,77]. SnO2 is very stable in carbonate molten salts. After electrolysis at 500 °C for 500 h, SnO2 inert anodes still remained intact in molten Li2CO3 Na2CO3–K2CO3 carbonates [16]. It is reported that the increasing LiF concentration in the cryolite melt can dramatically increases the rate of corrosion of SnO2 [76]. The absence of LiF and lower electrolysis temperatures may be the key reasons contributing to the enhanced stability of SnO2 in carbonate molten salts. SnO2 is also a stable inert anode in molten chlorides [66,77], and its corrosive behavior in molten chlorides is different than that in molten carbonates. CaCl2-based molten salts are the mostly used chloride electrolytes for CO2-electrosplitting. However, in CaCl2-based molten salts, CaSnO3 was formed at the SnO2 anode surface, leading to the decrease of electrical conductivity [69]. In addition, the electro-deposited alkaline or alkaline earth metals at the cathode can migrate to the anode, in which the SnO2 and CaSnO3 were reduced to low-valence tin oxides and soluble Sn [69]. Consequently, mass loss of the SnO2 anode took place. Generally, SnO2 shows a relative high stability in both carbonate and chloride molten salts. However, compared to the metal/alloy inert anodes, the electrical conductivity of SnO2 is still unsatisfactory, leading to a substantial voltage drop. 4.3 RuO2-based materials The formation of an insulating CaSnO3 layer on the SnO2 surface in CaO-containing molten salt leads to the dramatic decrease in electrical conductivity of SnO2 inert anodes. Unlike CaSnO3, both CaRuO3 and RuO2 are good semiconductors and can maintain a high electrical conductivity in CaO-containing molten salt. Therefore, RuO2-based inert anodes for CO2-electro-splitting in molten salts were explored [69]. Jiao et al. [69,78,79] investigated the corrosive and electrochemical behaviors of the CaRuO3 inert anode in CaCl2-based molten salts. The dissolution rate of CaRuO3 in pure CaCl2 molten salt is only 8.1 × 10−3 g cm−2 h−1, which can be further decreased by adding 1% CaO into the melt. After a 102 h of electrolysis in CaCl2 CaO molten salt, the corrosion of the inert anode is still negligible (as shown in Fig. 13 (a)–(c)), proving its stability as inert anode materials. Oxygen evolution at the RuO2-based inert anode was also detected in the chloride molten salts, as shown in Fig. 13(d). In addition to molten chlorides, the feasibility of the RuO2-based inert anodes in carbonate molten salts for oxygen evolution is also verified [22]. By using the RuO2-based inert anode, the schematic for the capture and electrochemical conversion of CO2 into CNT was suggested, as shown in Fig. 13(e). Although the RuO2-based inert anode shows a high stability in chlorides and carbonate molten salts, the high cost of RuO2 makes the RuO2-based inert anode an unlikely industrial option. Generally, two ways are adopted to reduce the cost. The first is to decrease the RuO2 ratio in the anode by combing with another low-cost semiconductor. Based on this method, RuO2-based inert anodes such as TiO2·RuO2 and CaTi(1- x )Ru x O3 were designed [78,79]. Another way is to use a thin layer of the conducting RuO2-based compound on a different substrate to replace the bulk RuO2-based semiconductor [69]. The above methods decrease the cost of RuO2-based inert anodes, however, the RuO2-based inert anodes still lack of practicability when considering the scarcity of Ru element. 4.4 Pt Other than the high cost, Pt is universally accepted as a good inert anode in many molten salts. During the CO2 electro-splitting process, Pt can also be used as the inert anode in both chloride and carbonate molten salts and shows a good oxygen evolution activity in molten salts [44,45,80,81]. In LiCl-containing molten salts, however, corrosion of Pt inert anode can take place. Jeong et al. [82] studied the corrosive behaviors of Pt inert anodes in pure LiCl and LiCl-1% Li2O molten salts. In the pure LiCl molten salt, surface spallation was observed after electrolysis, leading to the mass loss of the Pt inert anode. The corroded surface of the Pt inert anode mainly consisted of metallic Pt. Hence, it was speculated that the dissolution of Pt took place at grain boundaries, leading to a weakened adhesive strength between the grains. After the addition of 1% Li2O, the spallation of Pt inert anode was suppressed. Instead, a Li2PtO3 layer on the surface was found, which inhibited the dissolution of Pt. Therefore, corrosion of Pt inert anode in LiCl-based molten salt took place via two mechanisms. The first method is via the formation of Li2PtO3 at a high Li2O concentration while the other involves the direct dissolution of metallic Pt at a low Li2O concentration. In conclusion, Pt, Ni, RuO2 and SnO2 are the most investigated inert anode materials for CO2 electro-splitting in molten salts. All show good activities for O2 evolution, however, both Pt and RuO2 are scarce materials and are generally ruled out due to their expensive costs. Ni and SnO2-based materials are currently cheaper options and therefore present a higher practicability. In CaO-containing molten salts the formation of an insulating CaSnO3 layer at the anode surface can lead to the increase of over potential, reducing the feasibility of this material. Ni10Cu11Fe shows a high stability in carbonate molten salts at high temperatures due to the formation of an oxide layer, showing a great potential for long-term electrolysis. 5 Cost estimation and scale-up evaluation The original motivation for CO2 electro-splitting in molten salts is to help mitigate the greenhouse effect; however, high-value carbon products with superior properties were obtained at the cathode, increasing the desirability of this method. Furthermore, the anodic high-concentration oxygen gas can facilitate the industrial combustion process, which is also a valuable byproduct. It is being discussed worldwide, that imposing a carbon tax could help to reduce carbon emissions [6], which means CO2 electro-splitting could potentially lead to a carbon tax abatement for many enterprises. Therefore, CO2 electro-splitting in molten salts can provide cost outputs by obtaining value-added products at the cathodes and a carbon tax abatement. On the other hand, the electrode materials, molten salt electrolytes and heat for maintaining a high temperature as well as the energy consumption during electrolysis are the ingredients for cost inputs. The depletion of inert anodes (such as SnO2 and Ni10Cu11Fe anodes) is negligible, which means that the cost of electrode materials can be roughly ruled out. Therefore, the energy consumption for electrolysis process and maintaining a high temperature as well as the cost of molten salt electrolytes are the main ingredient for cost inputs [57]. Carbon capture and storage (CCS) contributes to the mitigation the greenhouse effect, therefore, CO2 electro-splitting in molten salt is desirable under the premise of environmental improvement. However, if the cost outputs are higher than that of inputs, this process will be profitable, leading to an attractive economic incentive. Therefore, cost estimation is necessary for the CO2 electro-splitting in molten salt to understand the economic stimuli. 5.1 Cost estimation 5.1.1 Electric energy inputs For CO2 electro-splitting in molten salts, the electrolysis and the heat for maintaining a high temperature are the main ingredients for electrical energy inputs. Considering that the heat dissipation of high-temperature molten salts can be compensated by the ohmic heat of the molten salts during electrolysis [83], the extra heat needed to be inputted is the reaction entropies [5]. The minimum energy consumption for CO2 electro-splitting reported to be between 10.4–10.8 kWh kg−1 CO2 [13,16,25]. A high absorption rate of 53.6 mmolCO2 h−1 molsalt −1 for CO2 was obtained after the addition of soluble oxides into the molten salts [2,17,22,29,47]. Taking an electrolysis cell containing 100 kg equimolar Na2CO3–Li2CO3 molten salts as an example, 62.9 kg CO2 can be electro-splitted per day, which means that between 654.2–679.3 kWh of electrical energy input is needed. On the other hand, CO2 electro-splitting by reaction (26) is endothermic and the corresponding entropy change is 394.5 KJ mol−1. This indicates that an extra 157 kWh of electrical energy is needed per day for the heating loss compensation. Using an electricity cost of $0.1 per kWh [57,62,84], the electric energy cost for CO2 electro-splitting of 62.9 kg is between $81.1 and 83.6 per day in an electrolysis chamber containing 100 kg equimolar Na2CO3–Li2CO3 molten salts. Therefore, the electric energy cost for electro-splitting of one tonne of CO2 is $1289–1328. This can be converted in roughly 16 days in the same electrolysis chamber. 5.1.2 Labor cost and capital expense Many similarities exist between the CO2 electro-splitting process in molten salts and the mature alumina electrolysis process. Firstly, electrolysis chambers with similar firebrick insulators and control equipment are used [57]. Secondly, in both cases, molten salt electrolytes are used. In addition, no noble electrode materials are used for both processes. Due to the similarities described above, the capital expense (cost of electrolysis cell, processing equipment and other ancillary facilities) and labor cost for the electro-splitting of CO2 in molten salts can be roughly estimated to be the same with that of the mature alumina electrolysis process. Both the labor cost and capital expense for alumina electrolysis are $150 per tonne [57]. However, Li2CO3, with a cost of roughly $6000 per tonne, is more expensive than that of cryolite [62]. However, Li2CO3 is not consumed during the CO2 electro-splitting process. It can be considered that one chamber of fresh molten salt electrolytes can be repeatedly used for roughly one year, then 22.5 tonnes CO2 can be electro-splitted during this period in an electrolysis chamber containing 100 kg equimolar Li2CO3 Na2CO3 molten salts. Correspondingly, the added cost of Li2CO3 is roughly estimated to be $10.5 for eletro-splitting one tonne CO2. Finally, after adding the cost of the molten salts electrolyte, the capital expense was increased to be $160.5 for electro-splitting one tonne CO2. It should be mentioned that the alumina electrolysis operates at approximately 960 °C in the cryolite molten salt, while CO2 electro-splitting operates under much milder conditions at between 450 and 750 °C, in less toxic carbonates or chlorides molten salts. Therefore, the non-consumable non-noble metal inert anodes can be adopted for the electro-splitting of CO2 while consumable carbon anodes are used for the alumina electrolysis process. This implied that the electrode cost can be negligible for CO2 electro-splitting in molten salts. Moreover, by using a eutectic Li2CO3 Na2CO3–K2CO3 molten salt, the amount of expensive Li2CO3 salt used can be further decreased, which means that the cost of molten salt electrolytes can be reduced. Based on the above facts, the capital cost should be lower than $160.5 for one tone CO2 electro-splitting. The comparison between the alumina electrolysis and CO2 electro-splitting process is shown in Table 2 . In an electrolysis chamber containing 100 kg eutectic Li2CO3 Na2CO3 molten salts, the cost for electro-splitting one tonne of CO2 is $1619 based on the average electricity energy consumption reported [16,25]. Although the electricity for electro-splitting one tonne CO2 is much higher than that for production of one tonne aluminium, the total cost for CO2 electro-splitting is still $261 lower due to the adoption of cheap non-consumable inert anodes and free CO2 as the raw materials. Furthermore, with the implementation of a carbon tax in many countries, electro-splitting of CO2 in molten salts can provide a carbon tax abatement for the enterprise, contributing to a further profit increase. Unlike the alumina electrolysis process, which is already very mature after development for more than 100 years, the CO2 electro-splitting process in molten salts is still under optimization and development. With deeper understanding of the electrode reactions, optimization on the electrode structures and electrolysis conditions, it is expected that the electrical energy input will be reduced in the future [5]. Licht et al. proposed a low electrical energy theory, displaying how one tonne of CNTs can be synthesized for $360 via CO2 electrolysis [5,62]. This indicates that there is a great potential to further decrease the electrical energy for the CO2 electro-splitting process. Compared to the alumina electrolysis process, the electro-splitting process can be driven by renewable energy such as solar energy [19,27,32,62,85], which is named the STEP process. Carbon deposition from the absorbed CO2 can take place at a low cell voltage of 2.0 V. By tuning the current density, the cell voltage for CO2 electro-splitting can be conducted at cell voltages as low as 1.3 V. Such a low cell voltage can be provided by a solar energy PV module, such as a silicon PV module. This further improves the CO2 electro-splitting process as an environmentally friendly process. However, the cell voltage for alumina electrolysis is high, up to 4.1 V [57], which means that the alumina electrolysis process driven by a solar energy PV module is not practical. 5.2 Profit evaluation As discussed above, the carbon tax abatement due to CO2 absorption and value-added carbon materials obtained on electrodes are the main cost outputs. The carbon tax has already been implemented in many countries. For example, the taxation for emission of one tonne CO2 is $30 in USA [57,84], which means that the carbon tax abatement for the enterprise will be $30 if one tonne CO2 is captured during the electro-splitting process in molten salts. Due to the continued deterioration of the environment, carbon taxation is likely to rise in the near future [6,57]. The CO2 electro-splitting products in molten salts are value-added carbon materials such as CNTs, CNFs, graphene and HCSs et al. Currently, the average value of the industrial CNTs produced by the chemical vapor deposition method is about $300,000 per ton [84]. 273 kg CNTs can be obtained from one tonne of CO2 by electrolysis in molten salts, which is valued $81,900. Based on the carbon tax abatement and the value of obtained CNTs, the cost outputs are roughly estimated to be about $81,930 from electro-splitting of one tonne CO2. By comparing the value difference between the output and total cost (as shown in Table 2), the profit from electro-splitting one tonne of CO2 in molten salts is high up to $80,311. Furthermore, taking an electrolysis cell containing 100 kg equimolar Li2CO3 Na2CO3 molten salts for example, 62.9 kg CO2 can be absorbed per day. Therefore, electro-splitting of one tonne CO2 can be fulfilled in about 16 days, resulting in a daily profit of roughly $5019. This means that CO2 electro-splitting in molten salts can provide an economic motivation. 5.3 Scaling-up evaluation At present, there is no reports of the scaling-up experiments for electro-splitting CO2 in molten salts. However, Licht et al. [1,57] verified that the CO2 electrochemical reduction process in molten salts is linearly scale-able with increasing area of the electrolysis chamber, as shown in Fig. 14 (a). In addition, the scaling-up by the STEP (Solar Thermal Electrochemical Photo) process has been anticipated [1,32,57]. It has been suggested that the CO2 STEP process can convert 7.8 × 103 moles of CO2 to solid carbon per day by using one square meter of concentrating photovoltaic (CPV). Correspondingly, 700 km2 of CPV is needed to eliminate the anthropogenic CO2 in ten years, turning the atmospheric CO2 concentration to the levels before industrial revolution [57]. This area of CPV is equivalent to less than 10% of the Sahara Desert. It is also suggested that the large CPV area needed could be set up above the open ocean, as illustrated in Fig. 14(b). Using this scaling-up estimation, ∼2 million tonnes of Li2CO3 would be required as the molten salt electrolyte. 6 Prospective In this review, CO2 electro-splitting in molten salts is summarized. The CO2 absorption process, cathodic reduction reactions and inert anodes corrosive behaviors as well as the morphologies of electro-deposited carbon are discussed. Although extensive investigations into the CO2 electro-splitting process have been conducted, many new phenomena on the surface of the electrode are still unknown. In addition, various carbon materials with different morphologies and properties have been obtained. To more precisely tune the product morphologies and functional attributes, the morphologies evolution mechanism of the cathode products needs to be understood more. Many aspects should be taken into careful consideration for practical applications. The long-term stability of inert anodes is key since for industrial practicability these anodes need to function for months or years; this should be tested before scaling-up practicability verification. Furthermore, instead of the atmospheric gas, using flue gas with a higher CO2 concentration can provide better dynamic conditions, thus be more suitable as the raw materials during the scaling-up process. Finally, many different operations exist for this new molten salt electrolysis process compared with alumina electrolysis. For example, the injection of CO2-containing flue gas into the high-temperature electrolytes as well as the separation of anode and cathode chambers are not needed for the alumina electrolysis process. Therefore, during a practical scaling-up process, the electrolysis cell and electrode structures for CO2 electro-splitting in molten salts should be carefully designed. Acknowledgments W. coredata.dc:description: Due to the serious greenhouse gas effects caused by the increasing concentration of atmospheric CO2, carbon capture and storage (CCS) has been an important area of research and many technologies are developed within this field. Molten salt CO2 capture and electrochemical transformation (MSCC-ET) process is a desirable method due to a high CO2 solubility, a wide potential window of molten salts and easily-controlled electrode reactions. Generally, electro-splitting CO2 in molten salts begins with CO2 absorption reactions to form CO3 2−, which is then followed by the carbon deposition at the cathode and O2 evolution at the anode. As a result, CO2 is electro-converted to O2 and carbon with different morphologies, compositions, microstructures and functional properties. This report introduces the MSCC-ET process, summarizes the reactions occurring in the molten salts and at the electrode surfaces, as well as the morphological variations of the cathodic products. The inert anode materials, cost estimation and scale-up evaluation of the process are then discussed. It is presumed that with a comprehensive understanding of the electrode reactions during electrolysis and the functional properties of carbon materials obtained during CO2 electro-splitting can provide a foundation for further developing this environmentally friendly process.
